item.title: Chinese Search Giant Baidu Stops Bitcoin Advertising
item.description:
Chinese Search Giant Baidu Stops Bitcoin Advertising

China's largest search engine, Baidu, has discreetly removed all bitcoin and virtual currency-related advertising from its online portals. China, the world's largest market for bitcoin will no longer see bitcoin-related advertising on the country's most-used search engine Baidu. The search engine giant moved to remove all cryptocurrency advertisements from its online portals this Thursday.

item.title: What The Heck Is Bitcoin? The Law Struggles For An Answer
item.description:
What The Heck Is Bitcoin? The Law Struggles For An Answer

As bitcoin spreads, courts and the police need to answer some basic questions including, is it money, property, or something else entirely?

item.title: Santander Backs Ethereum with Gold Sponsorship of Devcon2
item.description:
Santander Backs Ethereum with Gold Sponsorship of Devcon2

Santander, one of the biggest global banks with almost 200,000 employees and yearly revenue of more than $12 billion announced today the gold sponsorship of Devcon2, one of the biggest event of the year in the blockchain space to be held in just over three weeks.

item.title: Baidu Stops All Bitcoin-Related Advertising
item.description:
Baidu Stops All Bitcoin-Related Advertising

Baidu, China's largest search engine and web services company, has recently halted all Bitcoin and cryptocurrency-related advertising on its network. CnLedger, a Chinese media network which recently received a grant from the National Natural Science Foundation of China earlier this week, broke the news on August 25, 2016.

item.title: Traditional Crime Takes a Back Seat to Cyber Crime in a U.K. Study
item.description:
Traditional Crime Takes a Back Seat to Cyber Crime in a U.K. Study

Cybercrime as we all know is on the rise all over the world. Bank robberies happening from the comfort of one's home, where the robbers don't even have to leave they're computer chairs. It seems that one place in particular, the UK, is the number of cybercrimes has passed those of traditional crimes.

item.title: Austrailia receives $25.4 Million to Help Fight Dark Net Firearms Trade
item.description:
Austrailia receives $25.4 Million to Help Fight Dark Net Firearms Trade

The Australian federal government announced that they will be using the $25.4-million-dollar funding boost to combat the illegal firearms problem. "We know that modern technologies such as the dark web are enabling organized criminals to expand their reach globally and exert significant influence over Australia's black market, including drug trafficking, money laundering, extortion and firearms offences," Minister for Justice Assisting the Prime Minister for Counter Terrorism, Michael Keenan said.

item.title: Mass Surveillance is the Aim Of OnionDSL
item.description:
Mass Surveillance is the Aim Of OnionDSL

The UK is right around the corner from one of the biggest government surveillance power expansions since Snowden, and one network specialist isn't going to let that stop him from bringing privacy to the people.

item.title: Zero Day Exploits Are Easier To Find With This New System
item.description:
Zero Day Exploits Are Easier To Find With This New System

Arizona State University researchers created a way that makes gathering data from dark net markets and forums easy, and it helps identify new emerging cyber threats as they come out. The system uses search engines and dark net sites through the Tor network, and the researchers say they have found almost 30 marketplaces, and over 20 forums that black hat hackers are calling home.

item.title: First Bitcoin Related Crime Hits Punjab
item.description:
First Bitcoin Related Crime Hits Punjab

Police in Punjab are investigating their first ever case involving Bitcoin. Unfortunately, it also involves financial fraud data being purchased on the darknet. A group of four, two Punjab residents and two residence of the US stole Rs 1.2-crore worth of US Dollars using stole credit card data bought on darknet.

item.title: Utility Settlement Coin Aims to Set Industry Standard for Central Banking Digital Cash
item.description:
Utility Settlement Coin Aims to Set Industry Standard for Central Banking Digital Cash

A group of major banks; UBS, Deutsche Bank, Santander and BNY Mellon, as well as the broker ICAP, have teamed up to develop a new form of digital cash that will help to set an industry standard to clear and settle financial trades over a distributed ledger.
